DOC.HEAD: Ex-Deputy Chief Arrested on Wire Fraud Charge
DOC.TEXT: A former police deputy chief accused of cheating investors and stealing money from the Detroit Police Department was arrested Thursday on a federal charge of wire fraud, officials said. Kenneth Weiner was held without bond after a heariang before U.S. Magistrate Virginia M. Morgan, after prosecutors argued successfully that there was a risk the former civilian deputy chief would flee. Weiner was carryng had dozens of blank checks, credit cards and valid flight coupons when he was arrested early Thursday at Detroit Metropolitan Airport in Romulus, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Sheldon Light. The wire fraud charge is related to a pyramid investment scam in 1985 and 1986, U.S. Attorney Stephen Markman said. Earlier this month, Weiner was accused of stealing from a $1.4 million police secret service fund used for undercover operations. He had access to the fund from 1980 to 1986, when he left the department. The FBI, under a warrant issued by Morgan on Wednesday, arrested Weiner without incident as he stepped off a plane from Los Angeles, FBI Special Agent in Charge Hal Helterhoff said. Weiner's troubles began in 1986 when Caine Steel Co. of Detroit filed a civil lawsuit against him, charging that he defrauded the company of $379,000. He is suspected of duping as many as 90 investors out of about $20 million in a scheme that involved gold and silver trading. Weiner, 43, resigned as a deputy police chief in 1986 in the wake of allegations about the investment scheme. In his six years with the department, he advised police on security and anti-terrorism practices. Caine Steel's suit claimed Weiner said he represented COMSEC Corp. and could turn ``a sizable profit above current market interest'' on its investment. The alleged investment scheme used new investors' cash to provide large returns to previous investors. Such plans collapse when new investors can't be found. Earlier this month, Police Chief William Hart said Weiner stole money from the police secret service fund. Phony corporations set up by Weiner in California received checks from the fund. Weiner's companies paid $72,000 in rent for a Beverly Hills, Calif., house occupied by Hart's daughter and son-in-law. Hart signed checks to the corporations, but denies knowing anything about the rent paid on his daughter's home. Weiner disappeared in recent weeks as federal and city officials investigated the $1.4-million secret police fund. As of Thursday, no charges had been filed against him on alleged theft from the police department. Mayor Coleman Young this week reluctantly turned records of the fund over to city auditors, who found that key documents needed to trace money were missing. Police officials said a theft report was filed. Young initially balked at turning over the records because he said it could jeopardize undercover operations.
